wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Immersive Reader (EPUB Reader) application. Explain its purpose as a React-based EPUB reader with AI integration for contextual explanations, translations, and answers. Describe the core vision of enabling offline reading via OPFS storage and enhancing comprehension through AI-powered tools. Document the application's current status (Phase 3 AI Integration, v0.0.9), primary user workflows (upload, read, interact with AI, configure tools), and key differentiators such as context-aware AI agents, draggable/maximizable context menus, and mobile optimization. Include architectural highlights like the feature-based modular structure, strict TypeScript enforcement, and service-layer pattern. Use terminology consistent with the codebase including 'OPFS', 'AIAgent', 'ContextMenuSettings', and 'bookshelf'. Provide a high-level system context diagram showing user interaction with HomePage, EpubReader, and SettingsPage components, and their relationship to Redux store, services, and external AI providers. Address common beginner questions about the project's goals and scope.

wiki_catalogs.name: Route Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the application's route configuration using react-router-dom v6. Detail the structure defined in src/config/router.tsx, including the root routes ('/', '/reader/:bookId', '/settings') and nested child routes under '/settings'. Explain the use of layout routes with SettingsLayout and index routes for default navigation. Document the configuration of dynamic routes with parameters like :bookId and :id for tool editing. Describe how route elements are mapped to page components such as BookshelfPage, EpubReader, and SettingsLayout. Include examples of route definitions and explain the purpose of Navigate for redirection within the settings route. Address best practices in route organization, code splitting potential, and how the router integrates with the overall app structure.

wiki_catalogs.name: Store Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Redux store configuration. Explain the implementation of configureStore with the root reducer mapping, specifically focusing on the registration of the bookshelf slice. Detail the type-safe hooks useAppDispatch and useAppSelector, including their generic selector support and RootState type definition. Document the integration pattern with React Redux, showing how the store is provided to the application. Include examples from index.ts showing the store setup and hook exports. Address best practices in type safety, store modularity, and tree-shaking considerations. Discuss why counterSlice is defined but not included in the store and the implications for feature state management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Reusable UI Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the reusable UI components in the EPUB reader application. Describe the purpose and usage of each component: BookCard for displaying book metadata with cover, title, author, and progress; UploadZone for handling EPUB file uploads with drag-and-drop support; Breadcrumb and BackButton for navigation; Container for layout structuring; SearchableSelect for provider selection in settings; and icons.tsx for shared icon components. Document props, events, and accessibility features for each component. Provide practical usage examples from the codebase, such as how BookCard uses useBookDisplayData hook to format display data or how UploadZone integrates with OPFS storage. Explain composition patterns and how these components are used across different pages. Address common implementation issues like drag-and-drop event handling and responsive design considerations. Include performance optimization tips such as lazy loading for book covers.

wiki_catalogs.name: EPUB.js Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for EPUB.js integration in the application. Explain how the useEpubReader hook initializes the EPUB rendition using the EPUB.js library, including the setup of the container reference and configuration options like width, height, spread, and flow. Document the process of rendering the book into the DOM via the ReaderView component and the role of the renderTo method. Describe how the book instance is created from an ArrayBuffer and displayed with proper location restoration using CFI (Canonical Fragment Identifier). Include examples from useEpubReader.ts showing the initialization sequence, event binding, and error handling. Address common issues such as failed rendering due to invalid EPUB files, missing container references, or CORS restrictions when loading external resources. Provide performance tips for handling large EPUBs, including lazy loading and memory cleanup strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Agent Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AI Agent architecture. Explain how the AIAgent component orchestrates contextual AI interactions within the EPUB reader. Document the component's props including apiKey, api, model, and prompt, and how they configure AI behavior. Describe the internal state management for messageList and the use of AbortController for request cancellation. Detail the role of useFetchAIMessage hook in initiating and managing streaming AI responses. Explain the two view modes ('simple' and 'conversation') and their UI/UX implications. Illustrate how the component integrates with MessageList and InputBarRender to create a cohesive chat-like interface. Provide code examples showing how AIAgent is instantiated in the reading flow. Address lifecycle management including cleanup of ongoing requests on unmount. Include performance considerations for minimizing render cycles using useCallback and useRef.

wiki_catalogs.name: OPFS Storage Mechanism
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the OPFS (Origin Private File System) storage mechanism that enables persistent, offline book storage in the browser. Explain how the application leverages the File System Access API through OPFSManager to store EPUB files directly in the browser's private file system. Detail the initialization process in initializeBookshelf async thunk, including browser support detection and directory setup. Describe how books are stored as binary files with unique IDs and metadata, and how the getAllBooks function reconstructs the bookshelf state from stored files. Document the integration between Redux state management and OPFS persistence, including error handling for unsupported environments. Provide examples of how uploadBook and deleteBook interact with OPFS, and address storage quota limitations and performance considerations for large collections.

wiki_catalogs.name: Application Settings
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the general application settings interface. Explain the SettingsLayout component that provides the navigation rail and breadcrumb system for all settings pages. Document the General page as a placeholder for future preferences like theme and language settings. Describe the StoragePage for managing OPFS cache and the AboutPage for displaying version information. Detail how the settings routing is configured through react-router-dom and how navigation state is managed. Include examples of how new settings sections would be integrated into the existing layout. Address UI patterns such as responsive design between mobile and desktop views, accessibility considerations in navigation, and best practices for presenting 'coming soon' features. Provide guidance on extending the settings layout with new configuration sections.

wiki_catalogs.name: BookCard
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the BookCard component that displays book metadata and reading progress in the bookshelf view. Describe its visual appearance with book cover, title, author, progress bar, and action buttons. Document the component's props including book metadata, onOpen, and onDelete callbacks. Explain the internal logic using useBookDisplayData hook to format display values. Detail the accessibility features including keyboard navigation and ARIA labels. Provide usage examples showing how to integrate BookCard in a bookshelf grid. Include styling guidelines using TailwindCSS and performance considerations for rendering large collections. Address common issues like handling invalid book data and image loading errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: File Operations Utilities
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the file operations utilities. Thoroughly explain the performFileOperation function that provides consistent error handling and logging for all file operations. Document the fileToBase64 utility for converting files to Base64 format with proper error handling. Describe the safeGetFileHandle and safeGetDirectoryHandle functions that safely retrieve file and directory handles with appropriate error logging. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how components use these utilities when handling EPUB file uploads and OPFS interactions. Explain the integration with the logger utility for consistent application logging. Address common issues such as permission errors, file access failures, and how the utilities handle these gracefully. Provide guidance on performance considerations when processing large EPUB files and best practices for extending these utilities with new file operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bookshelf Slice
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the bookshelfSlice, the core state container for book management in the application. Explain its initialState structure including books (array of BookMetadata), isLoading (boolean for async operations), error (string for failure messages), and uploadProgress (tracking file upload status). Document the createSlice configuration with name 'bookshelf' and the reducers setUploadProgress and clearError that handle upload progress updates and error clearing. Detail the extraReducers handling for four async thunks: initializeBookshelf, uploadBook, deleteBook, and loadBooks, describing how each manages loading states and updates the state upon fulfillment or rejection. Include code examples showing how actions are dispatched from components and how selectors access bookshelf state. Explain the integration with OPFSManager for persistent storage operations and the validation logic within validateFile. Address error handling patterns, state normalization strategy for books, and performance considerations when managing large book collections. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like failed initialization due to OPFS unsupported environments or upload validation errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Initialize Bookshelf
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the initializeBookshelf async thunk. Explain its purpose in setting up the OPFS storage system and loading existing books on application startup. Document the three-phase logic: input handling (checking OPFS support), core processing (initializing OPFS and retrieving books), and output handling (returning book metadata). Describe how this thunk integrates with OPFSManager.initialize() and OPFSManager.getAllBooks() services. Provide examples of error handling when OPFS is not supported and how the rejected value is propagated through rejectWithValue. Explain the state transitions in the bookshelf slice via extraReducers and how the UI responds to loading and error states during initialization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Keyboard Navigation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the keyboard navigation system implemented in useKeyboardNavigator.ts. Explain how the hook uses useEffect to attach keydown event listeners and manage navigation state. Detail the support for standard arrow keys (ArrowLeft, ArrowRight) for page navigation and the special handling of mobile volume keys (VolumeUp, VolumeDown) when enabled via options. Describe the logic that prevents navigation when text is being selected using window.getSelection(). Document the cleanup mechanism that removes event listeners on unmount to prevent memory leaks. Provide code examples showing how goToNext and goToPrev functions are passed from the reader component. Address common issues such as event propagation conflicts and provide troubleshooting guidance for cases where keyboard events are not captured. Include performance considerations around event listener efficiency and the dependency array optimization in useEffect.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Selectors
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the state selector pattern used in the application. Explain the implementation of useAppSelector with generic typing for type-safe state access, as defined in src/store/index.ts. Detail how the RootState type is derived from the store's getState method and used to ensure type safety across the application. Provide practical examples showing how components select specific slices of state, such as bookshelf data, using selector functions. Discuss the benefits of centralized type definitions and how they improve developer experience. Address potential performance implications and recommend the use of memoized selectors via createSelector for complex computations, even though they are not currently implemented. Include guidance on avoiding unnecessary re-renders through proper selector design.

wiki_catalogs.name: Mobile Text Selection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the mobile text selection system. Explain the implementation in mobileSelection.service.ts, focusing on touchState management for tracking selection phases. Detail the long-press detection mechanism using setTimeout and TOUCH_TIMING constants. Describe the three-phase touch handling: touchstart initializes selection with elementFromPoint, touchmove extends the selection range using caret positioning, and touchend finalizes the selection. Document how startSelection identifies the target DOM element and creates initial caret ranges, while extendSelection dynamically updates the selection during finger movement. Provide examples of coordinate calculation for context menu positioning. Address common issues such as accidental selections, race conditions with computer selection handlers, and solutions for touch event propagation conflicts. Include performance considerations for frequent touchmove events and optimization strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Home Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the HomePage component, which serves as the primary bookshelf interface and entry point for the application. Explain its role in displaying the user's book collection using BookCard components, managing the upload workflow through direct drag-and-drop interactions, and providing visual feedback via the DragOverlay component. Document how it integrates with Redux store via bookshelfSlice to manage book state, handles file uploads through OPFS storage, and responds to user interactions like clicking the upload button to trigger the system file picker. Include implementation details of drag-and-drop event handling (dragenter, dragover, dragleave, drop) with proper state management to prevent flickering, and describe the use of hidden file inputs for seamless upload initiation. Provide examples of how the HomePage orchestrates state between upload actions and book display, handles loading and empty states, and maintains responsiveness across device sizes. Address common issues such as drag event propagation, file validation errors, and performance optimization when rendering large book collections.

wiki_catalogs.name: General Settings
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the main SettingsPage that serves as the central hub for application preferences. Cover the SettingsLayout component that provides consistent navigation and structure across all settings views. Document the GeneralPage as the default settings view, including its placeholder structure and planned configuration options like theme customization and language selection. Explain the StoragePage functionality for managing OPFS storage, displaying usage statistics, and providing cache management controls. Detail the AboutPage with version information, changelog access, and application metadata. Describe how the SettingsLayout organizes navigation between different configuration sections using breadcrumb navigation and consistent UI patterns. Provide examples of adding new settings panels, integrating with the layout system, and maintaining visual consistency across the settings interface. Address responsive design considerations for different screen sizes and accessibility requirements for settings navigation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technical foundation of the EPUB reader. Detail the frontend stack: React 18 with TypeScript (strict mode), Vite as the build tool, and Redux Toolkit for state management. Explain the role of core libraries: epubjs for EPUB rendering and navigation, openai SDK for AI integration, react-router-dom for routing, and @dnd-kit for drag-and-drop functionality. Describe the styling strategy using TailwindCSS with Prettier integration for class ordering. Cover storage mechanisms: OPFS for book persistence and LocalStorage for settings. Document development dependencies including ESLint, Prettier, and TypeScript configurations. Provide version compatibility details from package.json and explain why pnpm is the preferred package manager. Include practical examples of how these technologies work together, such as how Vite enables fast HMR during development or how TailwindCSS classes are applied in components like BookCard. Address common setup issues and dependency conflicts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for navigation patterns used throughout the application. Explain how the BackButton component leverages useNavigate from react-router-dom to enable history-based navigation, including conditional navigation with the 'to' prop. Provide code examples from BackButton/index.tsx showing the implementation of both relative (-1) and absolute path navigation. Discuss integration with UI elements like the EpubReader's NextPageButton and PrevPageButton for in-reader navigation, distinguishing between application-level and reader-specific navigation. Document common usage patterns across components, such as programmatic navigation in response to user actions. Address accessibility considerations, keyboard navigation support, and touch interactions. Include troubleshooting guidance for common navigation issues like event propagation conflicts and incorrect route transitions.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Slices
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the Redux slices in the application. Focus on bookshelfSlice as the primary state container, detailing its initialState structure with books, isLoading, error, and uploadProgress fields. Explain the createSlice pattern used for defining reducers like setUploadProgress and clearError. Contrast with counterSlice to illustrate simpler state management patterns. Document the domain-specific state organization and the rationale behind normalizing book data in the slice. Include code examples showing slice creation, action exports, and reducer registration. Address slice co-location with types and services, and discuss scalability considerations for adding new slices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Page-Level Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the page-level components that define the application's main views. Explain the structure and functionality of HomePage as the bookshelf interface with upload capabilities; EpubReader as the core reading experience with ReaderHeader and ReaderFooter for navigation controls; SettingsPage for application configuration; ContextMenuSettingsPage for AI tool management; and specialized pages like ToolEditPage and ToolExtractPage for tool customization. Document routing integration via router.tsx and how these pages consume Redux state from bookshelfSlice. Detail data flow from state to UI, including how book metadata is passed to components. Provide examples of page composition patterns, such as how EpubReader orchestrates multiple sub-components for rendering. Address lifecycle management, error handling, and loading states. Include guidance on adding new pages and integrating them with the existing routing and state management system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rendering Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the EPUB rendering configuration system. Explain the purpose and usage of the RENDERING_CONFIG constants defined in epub.ts, including WIDTH, HEIGHT, SPREAD, MIN_SPREAD_WIDTH, MANAGER, FLOW, and LOCATION_CHAR_COUNT. Describe how these values are used in createRenditionConfig within useEpubReader.ts to configure the EPUB.js rendition instance. Detail the impact of different configuration options on user experience, such as single vs. double-page spreads, scrolled vs. paginated flow, and text granularity for location tracking. Include how mobile-specific styles are applied via applyMobileStyles in style.util.ts to optimize readability. Provide practical examples of configuration adjustments for different screen sizes and reading preferences. Address troubleshooting steps for misaligned layouts, incorrect pagination, or font rendering issues by adjusting configuration parameters.

wiki_catalogs.name: Streaming Responses
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the streaming AI response system. Detail how useFetchAIMessage implements streaming from OpenAI-compatible APIs using ReadableStream and text decoder. Explain the onUpdateAIResponse callback mechanism that enables real-time UI updates as tokens arrive. Document the parsing of SSE (Server-Sent Events) chunks and handling of data, error, and done events. Describe how partial responses are incrementally rendered using react-markdown with proper typing effects. Illustrate the error handling strategy for network failures, API errors, and malformed responses. Provide examples of how streaming enhances user experience by reducing perceived latency. Address performance optimization through efficient DOM updates and memory management of large responses. Include troubleshooting guidance for common streaming issues like connection timeouts and CORS policies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Upload Process Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the EPUB upload process from user interaction to successful storage. Explain how the UploadZone component provides both drag-and-drop and file picker interfaces for uploading EPUB files, with visual feedback during the upload process. Detail the validation chain starting with isValidEpubFile and getEpubValidationError, which check file extension, size (MAX_EPUB_SIZE), and integrity before processing. Describe how handleFileUpload dispatches the uploadBook async thunk, triggering the Redux action flow from pending to fulfilled states. Explain the role of OPFSManager.uploadBook in saving the file to OPFS and extracting metadata via EPUBMetadataService. Include error handling for invalid files and upload failures, with user feedback through alerts. Provide code examples showing the integration between UploadZone, Redux actions, and the OPFS storage layer.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Provider Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for AI provider configuration system. Document the aiProviders.ts configuration file that defines available AI services with their endpoints, authentication requirements, and model specifications. Explain thinkingConfig.ts for controlling AI response behavior such as streaming, timeout, and retry logic. Describe the ApiConfig component for managing API key input and validation, and ModelSearchInput for selecting default models from provider offerings. Detail the security model for handling sensitive credentials in browser storage. Provide examples of adding a new AI provider like Anthropic or Mistral, including required configuration fields and endpoint patterns. Address error handling for invalid API keys, rate limiting scenarios, and fallback strategies. Include best practices for organizing provider configurations and maintaining compatibility across API versions.

wiki_catalogs.name: UploadZone
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the UploadZone component that enables EPUB file uploads through drag-and-drop or file selection. Describe its visual states including idle, drag-over, and uploading modes with appropriate feedback. Document the component's props, particularly the onUploadComplete callback. Explain the file validation process using isValidEpubFile and getEpubValidationError utilities. Detail the event handling for drag-and-drop operations and file input changes. Provide usage examples showing integration with Redux store via uploadBook action. Include accessibility considerations for keyboard users and screen readers. Address error handling for invalid files and upload failures. Document the maximum file size limit and accepted MIME types. Provide customization options for styling and user feedback messages.

wiki_catalogs.name: EPUB Validation Utilities
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the EPUB validation utilities. Thoroughly explain the isValidEpubFile function that validates EPUB files based on extension, size, and MIME type. Document the MAX_EPUB_SIZE, EPUB_EXTENSIONS, and EPUB_MIME_TYPES constants that define valid EPUB characteristics. Describe the getEpubValidationError function that provides user-friendly error messages for invalid files. Include the formatFileSize utility that converts byte sizes to human-readable formats. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how the UploadZone component uses these utilities to validate files before processing. Explain the relationship with EPUBMetadataService which relies on this validation. Address common issues such as incorrectly identified MIME types and how the validation handles edge cases. Provide guidance on extending validation rules for additional EPUB specifications or custom requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Counter Slice
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the counterSlice, a simple state slice used for demonstration and testing purposes. Explain its minimal initialState containing a single value property initialized to 0. Document the createSlice setup with the reducer setValue that directly updates the counter value. Highlight the export of the reducer and the custom hook useSetCountThunk that demonstrates async logic with a 1-second delay before dispatching the setValue action. Use this slice to illustrate basic Redux Toolkit patterns in contrast to the complex bookshelfSlice, showing how simple state can be managed without async thunks or extraReducers. Include usage examples showing how components can use useDispatch and useSelector with this slice. Address its role in the codebase as a learning tool or testing utility rather than a production feature. Discuss best practices for when to use simple reducers versus more complex async patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Upload Book
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the uploadBook async thunk. Explain its role in validating, processing, and storing EPUB files in OPFS. Document the validation logic using validateFile utility (file extension, size checks) and how invalid inputs are rejected with descriptive errors. Describe the integration with OPFSManager.uploadBook() service and the transformation of File input into BookMetadata output. Detail the state management flow through pending/fulfilled/rejected actions in the bookshelf slice, including how the new book is added to the state. Provide practical examples from HomePage where dispatch(uploadBook(file)).unwrap() enables promise-based handling for success feedback or error display. Include best practices for progress tracking and user feedback during upload.

wiki_catalogs.name: Text Selection Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the dual text selection system for different input methods. Explain the mobile selection implementation in mobileSelection.service.ts, including the touchState management, long-press detection with setTimeout, and the three-phase touch handling (touchstart, touchmove, touchend). Detail how startSelection identifies target elements using elementFromPoint and creates caret ranges, while extendSelection updates the selection during movement. Contrast this with the computer selection in computerSelection.service.ts that relies on mouseup and touchend events from the EPUB rendition. Document the shared handleSelectionEnd function that processes the final selection and triggers the AI context menu. Describe the TOUCH_TIMING constants that control selection behavior. Provide examples of how selection coordinates are passed to the context menu for positioning. Address common issues like selection conflicts mentioned in the changelog and provide solutions for race conditions between mobile and computer selection handlers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Custom Hooks
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for custom hooks used in the Redux state management system. Focus on useSetCountThunk from counterSlice.ts as a representative example of a custom hook that encapsulates async dispatch logic. Explain how useDispatch is abstracted within custom hooks to provide higher-level, reusable behaviors. Analyze how these hooks manage side effects, such as delayed state updates, and how they return actionable functions to components. Extend the discussion to real-world usage in bookshelf operations like uploadBook, deleteBook, and initializeBookshelf, which follow similar async thunk patterns. Provide code examples demonstrating how components consume these hooks for state manipulation. Discuss error handling, loading states, and how actions are typed using PayloadAction. Include best practices for naming, reusability, and testing custom hooks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Computer Text Selection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the computer text selection system. Explain the implementation in computerSelection.service.ts, focusing on its reliance on mouseup and touchend events from the EPUB.js rendition. Document how the selection handler captures the selected text range and coordinates, then processes them through the shared handleSelectionEnd function. Detail the integration with selection.service.ts for context extraction, including the use of MIN_CONTEXT_WORDS and MAX_NEIGHBOR_SEARCH constants to expand the selection context by traversing adjacent DOM nodes. Describe how the selected text is wrapped with <selected> XML tags for AI processing. Provide examples of how selection boundaries are calculated and passed to the context menu. Address common issues like selection loss on rapid mouse movements and solutions for handling overlapping event listeners. Include best practices for ensuring consistent behavior across different browsers and input devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: EPUB Reader Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the EpubReader page, which constitutes the core reading experience of the application. Detail its architecture as a composition of ReaderHeader and ReaderFooter for navigation controls, integration with EPUB.js through the useEpubReader hook for rendering and page turning, and handling of user interactions such as keyboard navigation and touch gestures. Explain how it manages the EPUB rendition lifecycle, subscribes to rendition events via renditionEvent.service.ts for synchronization, and maintains reading progress across sessions. Document the data flow from book loading to content rendering, including how chapter navigation, table of contents integration, and pagination are coordinated. Provide examples of how the page handles loading states, error conditions (e.g., corrupted EPUBs), and responsive layout adjustments. Address advanced topics such as performance optimization for large books, memory management of EPUB.js instances, and accessibility considerations for screen readers. Include guidance on extending the reader with custom controls or integrating additional UI elements.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Provider Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the AI provider configuration system that enables users to connect to various LLM platforms. Detail the ContextMenuSettingsPage as the central interface for AI configuration, including the provider selection dropdown that supports OpenAI, Anthropic, and 12+ other platforms through the AI_PROVIDER_CATALOG. Explain the API configuration workflow with fields for base URL and API key, connection testing functionality, and status visualization. Document the ModelSearchInput component that dynamically fetches available models from the selected provider's API. Describe the validation logic that ensures a default model is selected when AI tools are configured. Provide implementation examples for adding new AI providers to the catalog, configuring custom OpenAI-compatible endpoints, and handling provider-specific authentication requirements. Address security considerations for API key storage, rate limiting implications, and troubleshooting connection issues with different providers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on setting up the development environment and running the application. Provide step-by-step instructions for installing prerequisites: Node.js 18+ and pnpm. Detail the exact commands for installing dependencies (`pnpm install`), starting the development server (`pnpm dev`), building for production (`pnpm build`), and previewing the build (`pnpm preview`). Explain the importance of using pnpm instead of npm due to the lockfile. Include configuration requirements such as ensuring TypeScript strict mode is maintained. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like port conflicts, missing dependencies, or build errors. Include a quick start example showing how to upload an EPUB file and access the reader interface. Document the expected directory structure after installation and highlight critical files like main.tsx and index.html. Make this guide accessible to developers new to React or Vite while including expert tips about the development workflow.

wiki_catalogs.name: Route Parameters
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for handling route parameters in the application, focusing on the :bookId parameter in the '/reader/:bookId' route. Explain how dynamic segments are defined in the router configuration and accessed within the EpubReader component using useParams. Describe the data flow from URL parameter to loading the corresponding EPUB file from storage via the bookshelf state. Document error handling for invalid or missing book IDs, including potential redirection to the home page. Provide examples of constructing navigation links with parameters using Link or useNavigate. Discuss state persistence strategies and how reading progress is associated with specific book IDs. Address security considerations such as input validation and sanitization of route parameters.

wiki_catalogs.name: Async Thunks
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the async thunk middleware implementation. Detail each thunk action: initializeBookshelf, uploadBook, deleteBook, and loadBooks, explaining their async logic, error handling with rejectWithValue, and integration with OPFSManager services. Describe the pending/fulfilled/rejected action lifecycle and how extraReducers handle these states in the slice. Provide examples from HomePage where dispatch(uploadBook(file)).unwrap() is used for promise-based handling. Explain parameter validation patterns within thunks and error propagation to the UI. Include best practices for async error handling, loading state management, and avoiding race conditions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Composition Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the component composition patterns used throughout the EPUB reader. Analyze how complex UIs are built through composition of smaller, focused components, following the 'composition over inheritance' principle. Examine specific examples like BookCard composing BookCover, ProgressBar, and BookActions; or EpubReader assembling ReaderHeader, TOCSidebar, and ActionButtons into a cohesive reading interface. Document data flow through composed components, including prop drilling patterns and where Redux is used to avoid excessive prop passing. Explain the benefits of this approach for maintainability and reusability. Provide best practices for creating composable components with clear APIs and minimal coupling. Include performance considerations such as avoiding unnecessary re-renders in deeply composed trees and using React.memo appropriately. Address accessibility in composed components and how ARIA attributes are propagated.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation Controls
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the navigation system in the EPUB reader. Explain how the goToNext, goToPrev, and goToSelectChapter functions are implemented in useEpubReader.ts using EPUB.js's next(), prev(), and display() methods. Document the logic that prevents navigation beyond the start or end of the book by checking atStart and atEnd flags in the RenditionLocation object. Describe how chapter navigation is handled through the table of contents (TOC) and href-based routing. Detail keyboard navigation support via useKeyboardNavigator.ts, including arrow keys and volume button navigation on mobile devices. Include integration with NavigationControls.tsx for UI buttons and gesture handling. Provide examples of custom navigation enhancements and address common issues like unresponsive buttons, incorrect page transitions, or TOC synchronization problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Context Menu Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the context menu AI integration system. Explain how text selection in the EPUB reader triggers the context menu with AI tools. Document the configuration structure in aiProviders.ts that defines available AI services and their capabilities. Describe the ToolList component that renders configurable AI actions based on user settings. Detail how selected text is passed as context to AI prompts and how different tool types (AI, iframe) are handled. Illustrate the data flow from text selection to tool execution, including security considerations for external API calls. Provide examples of custom tool configurations and their use cases. Address the user experience of discovering and managing AI tools in the settings interface. Include implementation details on how the selection service captures and normalizes text selections across different devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Metadata Extraction System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the metadata extraction system that parses EPUB files to populate book information. Explain how extractMetadata uses epubjs to load the EPUB file from an ArrayBuffer and extract core metadata such as title, author, publisher, publication date, language, and ISBN from the container metadata. Detail the extraction of additional information like chapter count from the spine and cover image URL via book.coverUrl(). Describe the fallback mechanism that provides default values when metadata is missing or extraction fails. Explain how formatAuthors handles both string and array inputs, and how extractISBN identifies ISBN identifiers from the metadata. Document the integration with performFileOperation for error-resilient execution and logging via the logger utility. Provide examples of how extracted metadata is used to create BookMetadata objects stored in the bookshelf state.

wiki_catalogs.name: Custom Tools Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the custom tools management system. Explain the extensible tool architecture that allows users to create AI-powered or iframe-based context menu actions. Document the ToolList component for displaying and managing configured tools, and the ToolForm base component for tool creation/editing. Detail the AIToolForm for configuring AI prompt templates with variable injection (e.g., {{selection}}) and the IframeToolForm for embedding external web applications. Describe the ToolTypeSelector that enables switching between tool types and SectionCard for grouping related tools. Explain the useToolForm hook that handles form state and validation logic. Provide step-by-step examples of creating a translation tool, dictionary lookup, or web search integration. Address data persistence in LocalStorage, validation rules for tool configuration, and security considerations for executing user-defined tools. Include troubleshooting guidance for common issues like broken iframe integrations or malformed AI prompts.

wiki_catalogs.name: TOCSidebar
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the TOCSidebar component that provides chapter navigation within the EPUB reader. Describe its visual appearance as a collapsible sidebar with hierarchical chapter listing and current chapter highlighting. Document the component's props including tableOfContents, currentChapter, onChapterSelect, and onToggle. Explain the recursive rendering of nested TOC items with proper indentation levels. Detail the responsive behavior with mobile overlay and backdrop. Provide usage examples showing integration with EPUB.js navigation. Include accessibility features like keyboard navigation and screen reader support. Address styling customization using TailwindCSS and performance considerations for large TOC structures. Document the behavior when no table of contents is available.

wiki_catalogs.name: Application Logging System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the application logging system. Thoroughly explain the logger object with its log, info, error, and warn methods that provide consistent timestamped logging throughout the application. Document how the logger integrates with dayjs for time formatting and includes log levels for different message types. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how EPUBMetadataService and file operations use the logger to track metadata extraction, file operations, and error conditions. Explain the integration pattern where utilities and services import and use the logger for debugging and monitoring. Address common issues such as log verbosity in production and how developers can use these logs for troubleshooting. Provide guidance on extending the logger with additional features like log filtering, levels, or external logging services while maintaining the existing interface.

wiki_catalogs.name: Delete Book
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the deleteBook async thunk. Explain its purpose in removing books from OPFS storage by ID. Document the input validation (checking for valid bookId), the integration with OPFSManager.deleteBook(bookId) service, and the return of the deleted book ID upon success. Describe the state mutation in the bookshelf slice where the book is filtered out of the books array upon fulfillment. Explain error handling scenarios such as invalid IDs or deletion failures, and how these are surfaced to the UI via the rejected action and error state. Provide usage context showing how this thunk is typically dispatched from BookCard components with confirmation dialogs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Drag and Drop Upload
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the drag-and-drop interface for book importing. Explain the implementation in UploadZone component that handles dragover, dragleave, and drop events to provide visual feedback and process dropped files. Detail how the component uses state (isDragging, isUploading) to manage UI transitions and prevent multiple uploads. Describe the integration with epubValidation utilities to verify file type and size before upload. Document the DragOverlay component that displays a full-screen overlay when files are dragged over the home page, including its conditional rendering based on visibility. Explain the file input fallback mechanism with the hidden input element and label trigger. Provide examples of how the onUploadComplete callback is used to notify parent components. Address common issues like browser-specific drag behavior and provide troubleshooting guidance for cases where drop events are not triggered. Include performance considerations around file size validation and user experience during upload.

wiki_catalogs.name: Settings Pages
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the SettingsPage and related configuration pages that enable users to customize application behavior. Cover the SettingsPage as the main hub for application preferences, including navigation structure with SettingsLayout and integration with AboutPage and StoragePage. Then detail the ContextMenuSettingsPage as the central interface for managing AI-powered context tools, including configuration of AI providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, custom) through aiProviders.ts, model selection, API key management, and connection testing. Explain the architecture of tool management, including the creation, editing, and deletion of custom AI tools via ToolEditPage and ToolExtractPage, with emphasis on form handling through useToolForm and validation logic. Document how settings are persisted in LocalStorage, how AI provider configurations are structured, and how custom prompts are stored and applied during runtime. Provide examples of adding new AI providers, implementing custom tool types (AI, iframe), and ensuring secure handling of API credentials. Address common configuration issues, such as invalid API keys, rate limiting, and model compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Custom Tool Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the custom tool management system that allows users to create and configure AI-powered context menu tools. Cover the ToolExtractPage for adding new tools and ToolEditPage for modifying existing tools, both utilizing the shared useToolForm hook for state management. Explain the tool configuration interface with fields for name, short name, type (AI or iframe), and enable/disable toggle. Detail the AIToolForm with prompt templates using {selectedText} and {context} variables, reasoning mode toggle, and single/multi-word selection support. Document the IframeToolForm for embedding external web content. Describe the ToolList component that enables drag-and-drop reordering and inline management of tools. Provide examples of creating custom AI prompts for different use cases, implementing iframe tools for dictionary lookups, and organizing tool workflows. Address validation rules, error handling during tool creation, and the persistence mechanism for tool configurations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the React component system in the EPUB reader. Describe the high-level design principles: functional components with Hooks, PascalCase naming convention, and composition over inheritance. Document the component hierarchy starting from App.tsx through page-level components (HomePage, EpubReader, SettingsPage) to reusable UI components (BookCard, UploadZone, TOCSidebar). Explain props/state management patterns including prop drilling limitations and how Redux is used for global state. Detail lifecycle management using React Hooks like useEffect and custom hooks. Provide concrete examples from the codebase such as how BookCard receives book metadata as props or how ReaderHeader manages state for navigation controls. Include diagrams showing component relationships and data flow. Address performance considerations like memoization and lazy loading. Document integration patterns between components and services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Selectors and Custom Hooks
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the selector and custom hook patterns used for state access and manipulation. Explain the implementation of useAppSelector with generic typing for type-safe state selection. Detail how selectors can be created using memoization techniques (though not currently implemented, suggest createSelector patterns). Cover the useAppDispatch hook for type-safe dispatch operations. Analyze useSetCountThunk from counterSlice as an example of a custom hook encapsulating dispatch logic with async behavior. Provide usage examples showing how components subscribe to state changes and dispatch actions. Discuss performance implications of selector memoization and hook reusability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Reading Progress Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the reading progress tracking system. Explain how the 'relocated' event from EPUB.js is used in setupRenditionEvents to capture the current reading position via CFI (Canonical Fragment Identifier). Describe how the percentageFromCfi method calculates reading progress and converts it into page numbers based on generated locations. Document the use of latestReadingLocation storage manager to persist the last read position across sessions using OPFS. Detail how location generation is performed with a configurable character count threshold (LOCATION_CHAR_COUNT) to balance accuracy and performance. Include the integration between currentLocationRef, setCurrentPage, and setCurrentChapterHref for real-time UI updates. Provide examples of restoring progress on app restart and address issues like inaccurate progress saving, lost positions after reload, or incorrect page number calculations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Model Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for AI model configuration and provider management. Document the aiProviders.ts configuration file that defines supported AI services with their base URLs, default models, and metadata. Explain how the ApiConfig component allows users to select providers and manage API keys securely. Describe the migration strategy for backward compatibility with existing endpoint configurations. Detail the SearchableSelect component used for provider selection with filtering capabilities. Illustrate how selected providers auto-configure base URLs while allowing custom endpoints for OpenAI-compatible services. Provide guidance on adding new AI providers to the catalog. Address security considerations for API key storage in OPFS and validation of provider endpoints. Include troubleshooting steps for connection issues and model availability errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Deletion Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the book deletion workflow that removes books from both the UI and persistent storage. Explain how the deleteBook async thunk serves as the primary interface for deletion, validating the book ID before proceeding. Describe the interaction between Redux and OPFSManager.deleteBook, which removes the file from the Origin Private File System and cleans up associated metadata. Detail the state update in bookshelfSlice where the books array is filtered to remove the deleted book ID upon fulfillment of the thunk. Explain error handling in the rejected case, where deletion failures are captured and displayed to the user. Document how the BookCard component likely triggers deletion through a context menu or button action, dispatching the appropriate action. Address edge cases such as attempting to delete a currently open book and provide guidance on user confirmation patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: ReaderHeader
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the ReaderHeader component that provides top navigation controls in the EPUB reader interface. Describe its visual appearance with left, center, and right sections containing various control buttons. Document the component's props including visibility control and callback handlers for TOC, help, and settings. Explain the implementation of fullscreen toggle using browser APIs and navigation to home/settings pages using react-router. Detail the accessibility features and keyboard support. Provide usage examples showing integration with the main reader view. Include styling guidelines and responsive behavior. Address the transition effects for showing/hiding the header. Document the icon implementation using the shared icons system.

wiki_catalogs.name: EPUB Metadata Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the EPUB Metadata Service. Thoroughly explain the extractMetadata function that extracts comprehensive metadata from EPUB files including title, author, description, publisher, and cover information. Document the extractCoverImage, extractCoverBlob, and getCoverFormat functions that handle cover image extraction and processing. Describe the getBookByBookId function that retrieves book instances from OPFS storage. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how the BookCard component uses metadata for display and how the upload process relies on this service. Explain the integration with fileOperations utilities for error handling and OPFSManager for file storage. Address common issues such as malformed EPUB files, missing metadata, and cover extraction failures, and how the service provides fallback values. Provide guidance on performance considerations when processing large EPUB files and extending the service with additional metadata fields or processing capabilities.

wiki_catalogs.name: Load Books
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the loadBooks async thunk. Explain its function in refreshing the bookshelf by retrieving all books from OPFS storage. Document the core processing step that calls OPFSManager.getAllBooks() and returns the book list, along with error handling using rejectWithValue for storage access failures. Describe how this thunk differs from initializeBookshelf by focusing solely on data retrieval without initialization. Explain the state update pattern in the bookshelf slice where the entire books array is replaced upon fulfillment. Provide usage scenarios such as manual refresh actions or post-deletion reloads, and how loading states are managed to prevent UI flicker during the operation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Reader Help Overlay
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the ReaderHelpOverlay that guides new users through interaction zones. Explain how the overlay component provides visual cues for available gestures and interactions within the EPUB reader interface. Document its implementation details including the fixed positioning, z-index layering, and backdrop blur effects for focus. Describe the timing mechanism or trigger conditions that control when the overlay is displayed (e.g., first-time user, new feature introduction). Detail the content hierarchy within the overlay, including icons, headings, and instructional text that explain navigation and selection capabilities. Explain how the component integrates with the reader's state management to track user progress and dismiss the overlay appropriately. Provide examples of how it enhances onboarding for features like text selection and AI context menu access. Address accessibility considerations for users with different needs and provide guidance on customizing the help content for different user segments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Routing & Navigation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the application's routing system. Document the implementation using react-router-dom v6 with routes defined in src/config/router.tsx. Explain the route structure: '/', '/reader/:bookId', '/settings', '/tool-edit', and '/tool-extract'. Describe how navigation works between HomePage (bookshelf), EpubReader (reading interface), and SettingsPage. Detail the use of route parameters like bookId for loading specific EPUB files. Provide examples of navigation patterns in components using useNavigate and Link. Explain how the BackButton component integrates with the routing history. Document error handling for invalid routes and route guards if implemented. Include performance considerations for route loading and code splitting strategies. Address common issues like navigation state persistence and deep linking into specific book locations.

wiki_catalogs.name: ReaderFooter
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the ReaderFooter component that displays reading progress and page navigation controls. Describe its visual appearance with progress bar, page counter, and next/previous buttons. Document the component's props including currentPage, totalPages, and navigation callbacks. Explain the progress calculation and visual representation using the TailwindCSS-based progress bar. Detail the accessibility features and keyboard navigation support. Provide usage examples showing integration with the EPUB rendering system. Include styling customization options and responsive behavior. Address the transition effects for showing/hiding the footer. Document the disabled state handling for navigation buttons at book boundaries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Mobile Optimization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on mobile-specific optimizations. Explain the volume button navigation feature enabled through the enableVolumeKeys option in useKeyboardNavigator.ts, including how preventDefault is used to suppress system volume changes while repurposing the hardware buttons for page turning. Detail the mobile selection system that implements long-press detection for text selection, with configurable timing thresholds from TOUCH_TIMING constants. Describe the applyMobileStyles utility that adjusts the reader interface for touch interaction. Document the responsive design considerations in the reader components that ensure touch targets are appropriately sized. Provide examples of how these features improve the reading experience on mobile devices without physical keyboards. Address common issues like browser permission requirements for intercepting volume keys and provide troubleshooting guidance for inconsistent touch event behavior across different mobile platforms. Include performance considerations around touch event handling frequency and memory usage on resource-constrained devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Styling Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the TailwindCSS implementation. Explain the utility-first approach and how it's configured in tailwind.config.js with project-specific themes, spacing, and breakpoints. Document the styling workflow including how classes are applied directly in JSX, the use of Prettier with tailwindcss plugin for class sorting, and the 2-space indentation convention. Describe how global styles are managed in src/index.css and how component-specific styles are handled. Provide examples from components like BookCard showing responsive design patterns and hover states. Explain dark mode implementation if present. Address accessibility considerations in styling decisions and performance optimization through PurgeCSS. Include guidance on creating new components with consistent styling and troubleshooting common Tailwind issues like missing classes or specificity conflicts.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Redux Toolkit implementation. Describe the store structure with slices for different domains (bookshelf, counter). Explain the bookshelfSlice as the primary state container for managing uploaded books, loading states, and errors. Detail the use of createSlice for reducers and actions, and configureStore for setup. Document async thunk patterns for handling asynchronous operations like book upload and metadata extraction. Explain selector patterns using createSelector for optimized data retrieval. Provide examples of state interactions from components like HomePage dispatching actions to update bookshelf state. Include diagrams showing data flow from user action to reducer to UI update. Address performance considerations like state normalization and memoization. Discuss trade-offs of using Redux Toolkit versus React Context for different state types.

wiki_catalogs.name: EPUB Rendering System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the EPUB.js integration and rendering pipeline. Document how the useEpubReader hook initializes the EPUB rendition, handles navigation (previous/next page), and manages reading progress tracking. Explain the role of renditionEvent.service.ts in handling EPUB.js events like 'relocated' and 'displayed'. Describe metadata extraction process through EPUBMetadataService.ts for displaying book information. Detail the rendering configuration including iframe usage, content styling, and pagination. Provide examples of how the ReaderView component integrates with the EPUB.js rendition object. Address performance considerations for large EPUB files and memory management. Include troubleshooting guidance for common rendering issues like font loading failures or incorrect pagination.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the AI agent architecture and integration. Document how the AIAgent component provides contextual assistance by analyzing selected text from EPUB content. Explain the streaming response pattern from AI providers and how responses are rendered using react-markdown. Describe the configuration system in aiProviders.ts that enables extensibility across different AI services. Detail the context menu integration that allows users to trigger AI tools from text selection. Explain the drilldown selection capability that enables following up on AI responses. Provide examples of how user messages and assistant responses are managed in the MessageList component. Address rate limiting, error handling for API failures, and security considerations for API key management. Include performance optimization for minimizing latency in AI interactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Book Management System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the book upload, storage, and organization system. Document the OPFS-based storage mechanism that enables offline book persistence in the browser. Explain the upload process from the UploadZone component through file validation to storage in OPFS. Describe metadata extraction using EPUBMetadataService.ts to populate book information in the bookshelf. Detail the Redux state management in bookshelfSlice.ts for tracking uploaded books, loading states, and errors. Provide examples of how the HomePage displays the bookshelf using BookCard components. Explain book deletion workflow and error handling for corrupted EPUB files. Address performance considerations for managing large book collections and storage quota limitations in OPFS.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the key UI components in the application. Describe the BookCard component's visual appearance, behavior, and props for displaying book metadata and progress. Document the UploadZone component's drag-and-drop interface and file handling logic. Explain the TOCSidebar component's collapsible chapter navigation and synchronization with reading position. Detail the ReaderHeader and ReaderFooter components' controls for navigation, settings access, and reading assistance. For each component, document props/attributes, events, and customization options. Include usage examples with code snippets showing how to implement these components. Provide accessibility guidelines and responsive design considerations. Address common styling issues and performance optimization for rendering large lists of BookCards.

wiki_catalogs.name: Utility Functions and Services
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the utility functions and service layer. Document the fileOperations.ts utilities for handling file reading and writing operations with OPFS. Explain the epubValidation.ts functions for validating EPUB file integrity before processing. Describe the logger.ts implementation for consistent application logging. Detail the EPUBMetadataService.ts service for extracting title, author, and cover information from EPUB files. Explain the separation of concerns between utils (general-purpose functions) and services (business logic). Provide examples of how components use these utilities and services. Address error handling patterns and performance considerations for file-intensive operations. Include guidance on extending the utility library with new functions while maintaining code quality standards.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration and Settings
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on application configuration and user settings. Document the configuration files in src/config including aiProviders.ts for AI service endpoints and thinkingConfig.ts for AI behavior parameters. Explain the SettingsPage interface for general application preferences and the ContextMenuSettingsPage for AI tool configuration. Detail the custom tool system that allows users to create, edit, and manage AI and iframe tools. Describe the global default model selector and provider configuration system. Explain how settings are persisted in LocalStorage. Provide examples of configuring a new AI provider or creating a custom translation tool. Address security considerations for storing API keys and best practices for configuration management across environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Advanced Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the advanced functionality that enhances user experience. Document the keyboard navigation system implemented in useKeyboardNavigator.ts for efficient reading control. Explain the text selection handling with separate services for computerSelection and mobileSelection to accommodate different input methods. Describe the drag-and-drop interface in UploadZone for intuitive book importing. Detail the ReaderHelpOverlay that guides new users through interaction zones. Address mobile optimization features including volume button navigation and touch-friendly controls. Provide examples of how these features improve accessibility and usability. Include performance considerations for event handling and memory usage. Address common issues like selection conflicts and provide troubleshooting guidance.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: EPUB Reader Application

## 1. Project Introduction

The EPUB Reader application is a modern web-based e-book reader designed to provide a seamless reading experience for EPUB format books. Built with React and TypeScript, the application leverages modern web technologies to deliver a feature-rich reading interface with AI integration capabilities.

**Core Goals and Objectives:**
- Provide a clean, intuitive interface for reading EPUB books
- Implement robust book management functionality
- Support AI-powered reading assistance features
- Enable cross-device synchronization of reading progress
- Offer customizable reading settings and tools

**Target Audience:**
- Digital book readers who prefer EPUB format
- Users seeking enhanced reading experiences with AI assistance
- Developers interested in EPUB parsing and rendering technologies
- Privacy-conscious users who prefer client-side book storage

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The application follows a modular architecture with clear separation of concerns, organized into several key directories:

- **src/components**: Reusable UI components like BookCard, UploadZone, and navigation elements
- **src/pages**: Page-level components representing different views (EpubReader, SettingsPage, etc.)
- **src/store**: Redux-based state management for application state
- **src/services**: Business logic and service layers for EPUB processing and storage
- **src/hooks**: Custom React hooks for encapsulating reusable logic

### Design Patterns

The application employs several modern design patterns:

- **Redux Toolkit Pattern**: Centralized state management with slices for different domains
- **Custom Hooks Pattern**: Reusable logic encapsulation in hooks like `useEpubReader` and `useKeyboardNavigation`
- **Component Composition**: Hierarchical component structure with specialized sub-components
- **Async Thunk Pattern**: Handling asynchronous operations in Redux with proper loading/error states

### System Relationships

```mermaid
flowchart TD
  A[Client] --> B[React UI Layer]
  B --> C[Redux Store]
  C --> D[EPUB Services]
  D --> E[OPFS Storage]
  B --> F[EPUB.js Library]
  F --> G[EPUB Files]
  C --> H[AI Services]
  H --> I[OpenAI API]
```

### Data Flow

```mermaid
flowchart LR
  A[User Interaction] --> B[React Component]
  B --> C[Redux Action]
  C --> D[Async Thunk]
  D --> E[Service Layer]
  E --> F[Data Storage/External API]
  F --> G[Response]
  G --> H[Redux Reducer]
  H --> I[Updated State]
  I --> J[UI Re-render]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- [main.tsx](src/main.tsx): Application entry point that initializes React, Redux, and routing
- [index.html](index.html): HTML template for the application

### Core Modules
- [bookshelfSlice.ts](src/store/slices/bookshelfSlice.ts): Manages bookshelf state including book collection, loading states, and errors
- [useEpubReader.ts](src/pages/EpubReader/hooks/useEpubReader.ts): Core hook for EPUB rendering and navigation functionality
- [EPUBMetadataService.ts](src/services/EPUBMetadataService.ts): Service for extracting metadata from EPUB files

### Configuration Approach
- [vite.config.ts](vite.config.ts): Vite build configuration with React plugin and path aliases
- [router.tsx](src/config/router.tsx): React Router configuration defining application routes
- [tailwind.config.js](tailwind.config.js): Tailwind CSS configuration for styling

### External Dependencies
- [package.json](package.json): Lists dependencies including React, Redux Toolkit, EPUB.js, and OpenAI SDK
- [aiProviders.ts](src/config/aiProviders.ts): Configuration for AI service providers

### Integration Points
- [renditionEvent.service.ts](src/pages/EpubReader/services/renditionEvent.service.ts): Integration with EPUB.js rendering events
- [OPFSManager](src/services/OPFSManager): Integration with the Origin Private File System for persistent storage

### Component Relationships

```mermaid
graph TD
  App[App Component] --> Router[React Router]
  Router --> HomePage[HomePage]
  Router --> EpubReader[EpubReader]
  Router --> SettingsLayout[SettingsLayout]
  SettingsLayout --> GeneralPage[GeneralPage]
  SettingsLayout --> StoragePage[StoragePage]
  SettingsLayout --> ContextMenuSettingsPage[ContextMenuSettingsPage]
  
  EpubReader --> AIAgent[AIAgent Component]
  EpubReader --> ReaderHeader[ReaderHeader]
  EpubReader --> ReaderFooter[ReaderFooter]
  EpubReader --> TOCSidebar[TOCSidebar]
  
  App --> ReduxStore[Redux Store]
  ReduxStore --> bookshelfSlice[bookshelfSlice]
  
  EpubReader --> useEpubReader[useEpubReader Hook]
  useEpubReader --> EPUBMetadataService[EPUBMetadataService]
  useEpubReader --> renditionEventService[renditionEvent.service]
  
  HomePage --> BookCard[BookCard]
  BookCard --> UploadZone[UploadZone]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview

The EPUB Reader application provides a comprehensive set of features for managing and reading EPUB books:

1. **Book Management**: Upload, store, and organize EPUB books using the browser's Origin Private File System
2. **EPUB Rendering**: Display EPUB content with proper formatting using the EPUB.js library
3. **Reading Progress**: Track and restore reading position across sessions
4. **AI Assistance**: Integrated AI agent for answering questions about the text
5. **Customizable Interface**: Adjustable reading settings and themes
6. **Table of Contents**: Navigate through book chapters with a collapsible TOC sidebar
7. **Mobile Support**: Touch-friendly interface with volume button navigation on mobile devices

### Implementation Highlights

**Bookshelf State Management**
The application uses Redux Toolkit to manage the bookshelf state, with async thunks for handling asynchronous operations like initializing the bookshelf, uploading books, and deleting books. The state includes books array, loading status, error messages, and upload progress.

Sources:
- [bookshelfSlice.ts](src/store/slices/bookshelfSlice.ts#L1-L189)

**EPUB Rendering System**
The core reading functionality is implemented in the `useEpubReader` hook, which integrates with the EPUB.js library to render books, handle navigation, and manage reading state. The hook sets up event listeners for selection, clicks, and location changes.

Sources:
- [useEpubReader.ts](src/pages/EpubReader/hooks/useEpubReader.ts#L1-L201)

**Metadata Extraction**
The application extracts comprehensive metadata from EPUB files including title, author, publisher, publication date, language, ISBN, and cover image. This is handled by the `EPUBMetadataService` which uses EPUB.js to parse the file and extract relevant information.

Sources:
- [EPUBMetadataService.ts](src/services/EPUBMetadataService.ts#L1-L177)

**AI Integration**
The application includes an AI agent component that can analyze text selections and provide intelligent responses. This feature integrates with the OpenAI API to provide natural language processing capabilities.

Sources:
- [AIAgent.tsx](src/pages/EpubReader/components/AIAgent/AIAgent.tsx)

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
  [*] --> Initial
  Initial --> Bookshelf: App Load
  Bookshelf --> BookUpload: User Uploads Book
  BookUpload --> MetadataExtraction: Extract Metadata
  MetadataExtraction --> BookStorage: Save to OPFS
  BookStorage --> Bookshelf: Update UI
  
  Bookshelf --> BookOpen: User Opens Book
  BookOpen --> EPUBRendering: Render with EPUB.js
  EPUBRendering --> Reading: User Reads
  Reading --> TextSelection: User Selects Text
  TextSelection --> AIProcessing: Send to AI Agent
  AIProcessing --> AIResponse: Display Answer
  
  Reading --> Navigation: User Navigates
  Navigation --> ProgressSave: Save Reading Position
  ProgressSave --> Reading: Continue Reading
```
</blog>

wiki_repo.name: com.wuchuheng.epub-reader
